Vector Space over a Field

Vector spaces over a field are a special case of the more general notion of modules over a ring. Normally, textbooks define a vector space as a set equipped with two operations which obey a long list of axioms:

An (abstract) vector space (V,F,+,⋅)(V,\mathbb{F},+,\cdot)(V,F,+,⋅) consists of

  1. A field F\mathbb{F}F, whose elements are called scalars
  2. A set VVV, whose elements are called (abstract) vectors
  3. A rule (+):V×V→V(+) : V \times V \rightarrow V(+):V×V→V for vector addition, satisfying
    1. (associativity) u+(v+w)=(u+v)+wu+(v+w)=(u+v)+wu+(v+w)=(u+v)+w
    2. (commutativity) u+v=v+uu+v = v+uu+v=v+u
    3. (additive identity) exists 0∈V0 \in V0∈V with v+0=vv + 0 = vv+0=v for all v∈Vv \in Vv∈V
    4. (additive inverse) for all v∈Vv \in Vv∈V, exists (−v)∈V(-v) \in V(−v)∈V with v+(−v)=0v + (-v) = 0v+(−v)=0
  4. A rule (⋅):F×V→V(\cdot) : \mathbb{F} \times V \rightarrow V(⋅):F×V→V for scalar multiplication, satisfying
    1. (scalar identity) 1F⋅v=v1_F \cdot v = v1F​⋅v=v for all v∈Vv \in Vv∈V
    2. (compatibility) (αβ)v=α(β(v))(\alpha \beta) v = \alpha(\beta(v))(αβ)v=α(β(v))
    3. (distributes over vector addition) α(v+w)=αv+αw\alpha (v + w) = \alpha v + \alpha wα(v+w)=αv+αw
    4. (distributes over field addition) (α+β)v=αv+βv(\alpha + \beta) v = \alpha v + \beta v(α+β)v=αv+βv

We can state these properties more concisely by noticing that Property III is equivalent to the requirement that (V,+)(V,+)(V,+) forms a commutative group.

An (abstract) vector space over the field F\FFF is a commutative group (V,+)(V,+)(V,+) together with a rule (⋅):F×V→V(\cdot) : \FF \times V \rightarrow V(⋅):F×V→V satisfying

  1. (scalar identity) 1F⋅v=v1_F \cdot v = v1F​⋅v=v for all v∈Vv \in Vv∈V
  2. (compatibility) (αβ)v=α(β(v))(\alpha \beta) v = \alpha(\beta(v))(αβ)v=α(β(v))
  3. (distributes over addition) α(v+w)=αv+αw\alpha (v + w) = \alpha v + \alpha wα(v+w)=αv+αw
  4. (distributes over field addition) (α+β)v=αv+βv(\alpha + \beta) v = \alpha v + \beta v(α+β)v=αv+βv

Definitions 1a and 1b seem to present the set VVV as the primary object of interest, relegating the scalars F\FFF to the sidelines. The key to understanding modules is to turn this presumption on its head by treating F\FFF as the distinguished object instead.

By partial application of the scaling operator (⋅):F×V→V(\cdot) : \FF \times V \rightarrow V(⋅):F×V→V, each scalar α∈F\alpha \in \FFα∈F corresponds to a linear map φa:v↦αv\varphi_a : v \mapsto \alpha vφa​:v↦αv from VVV to itself. Linear self-maps on VVV constitute the endomorphism ring (End(V),+,∘)(\End(V), +, \circ)(End(V),+,∘), whose operations are pointwise addition and function composition. The vector space axioms ensure that the map φ⊡:F→(V→V)\varphi_\boxdot : \FF \rightarrow (V \rightarrow V)φ⊡​:F→(V→V) from field elements to linear self-maps is a ring homomorphism. We arrive at our third and final definition,

An (abstract) vector space over the field F\FFF is a commutative group (V,+)(V,+)(V,+) together with a ring homomorphism φ:F→End(V)\varphi : \FF \rightarrow \mathrm{End}(V)φ:F→End(V).

The ring homomorphism defines the additive and multiplicative group actions on VVV by scalars from the field F\FFF.

Module over a Ring

For modules, we require only that the set acting on VVV be a ring, rather than a field.

A module over the ring RRR is a commutative group (M,+)(M,+)(M,+) together with a ring homomorphism φ:R→End(M)\varphi : R \rightarrow \End(M)φ:R→End(M) defining an action of RRR on MMM, where End(M)\End(M)End(M) is the set of group homomorphisms M→MM \rightarrow MM→M.

Modules over a ring RRR are called RRR-modules, for short. An RRR-module is called left if it arises from a left action, and right otherwise. As for vector spaces, we could unfold this definition into a list of axioms, but this would obfuscate the real purpose of modules: Many mathematical objects happen to be rings, and modules allow us to study rings by their action on a set (much like we can study groups via their representations).

Let MMM be an RRR-module. An of MMM is a subgroup N⩽(M,+)N \subgroup (M,+)N⩽(M,+) closed under the ring action, rn∈Nrn \in Nrn∈N for r∈Rr \in Rr∈R, n∈Nn \in Nn∈N.

Several important examples of modules are listed below.

  • If F\FFF is a field, then F\FFF-modules and F\FFF-vector spaces are identical.
  • Every ring RRR is an RRR-module over itself. In particular, every field F\FFF is an F\FFF-vector space. Submodules of RRR as a field over itself are ideals.
  • If SSS is a subring of RRR with 1S=1R1_S = 1_R1S​=1R​, every RRR-module is an SSS-module.
  • If GGG is a commutative group of finite order mmm, then m⋅g=0m \cdot g=0m⋅g=0 for all g∈Gg \in Gg∈G, and GGG is a (Z/mZ)(\ZZ / m \ZZ)(Z/mZ)-module. In particular, if GGG has prime order ppp, then GGG is a vector space over the field (Z/pZ)(\ZZ/ p \ZZ)(Z/pZ).
  • The smooth real-valued functions C∞(M)\mathscr{C}^\infty(\mathcal{M})C∞(M) on a smooth manifold form a ring. The smooth vector fields on M\mathcal{M}M form a C∞(M)\mathscr{C}^\infty(\mathcal{M})C∞(M)-module.
  • For a ring RRR, every RRR-algebra has natural (left/right) RRR-module structure given by the (left/right) ring action of RRR on AAA.

(Z\ZZZ-modules) By definition, every Z\ZZZ-module is a commutative group. Likewise, every commutative group (G,+)(G,+)(G,+) becomes a Z\ZZZ-module under the ring action defined for n∈Zn \in \ZZn∈Z, g∈Gg \in Gg∈G by n⋅g={−a+a+⋯+a−(n times)if n>0−0if n=0−a−a−⋯−a(−n times)if n<0 n \cdot g = \begin{cases} \hphantom{-}a + a + \cdots + a \quad \hphantom{-}\text{(} n \text{ times)} & \text{if } n > 0 \\ \hphantom{-}0 & \text{if } n = 0 \\ -a - a - \cdots - a \quad \text{(} {-}n \text{ times)} & \text{if } n < 0 \end{cases} n⋅g=⎩⎨⎧​−a+a+⋯+a−(n times)−0−a−a−⋯−a(−n times)​if n>0if n=0if n<0​ We conclude that Z\ZZZ-modules and commutative groups are one in the same.

Modules over a Polynomial Ring F[x]\FF[x]F[x]

The polynomial ring F[x]\FF[x]F[x] is the space of formal linear combinations of powers of an indeterminate xxx, with coefficients drawn from an underlying field F\FFF. p(x)=p0+p1x+p2x2+⋯+pdxm(m∈N) p(x) = p_0 + p_1 x + p_2 x^2 + \cdots + p_d x^m \quad (m \in \NN) p(x)=p0​+p1​x+p2​x2+⋯+pd​xm(m∈N)

Polynomials form a ring under entrywise addition and discrete convolution of coefficient sequences. The sum and product of p,q∈F[x]p, q \in \FF[x]p,q∈F[x] have coefficients [p+q]k=pk+qk[p⋅q]k=∑j=0max⁡(n,m)pjqk−j \begin{aligned} [p+q]_k &= p_k + q_k & [p\cdot q]_k &= \sum_{j=0}^{\max(n,m)} p_j q_{k-j} \end{aligned} [p+q]k​​=pk​+qk​​[p⋅q]k​​=j=0∑max(n,m)​pj​qk−j​​

Consider what it would mean for an F\FFF-vector space VVV to be an F[x]\FF[x]F[x]-module. We need a ring homomorphism φ:F[x]→End(V)\varphi : \FF[x] \rightarrow \End(V)φ:F[x]→End(V) describing the action of polynomials on vectors. Since φ\varphiφ preserves sums and products between F[x]\FF[x]F[x] and (End(V),+,∘)(\End(V),+,\circ)(End(V),+,∘) as rings, we find that the choice of a single linear map φ(x)∈End(V)\varphi(x) \in \End(V)φ(x)∈End(V) determines the value of φ\varphiφ on arbitrary polynomials~p∈F[x]p \in \FF[x]p∈F[x], φ(p)v=φ(∑k=1mpkxk)v=∑k=1mpkφ(x)kv \begin{aligned} \varphi(p) v = \varphi\left( \sum_{k=1}^m p_k x^k \right) v = \sum_{k=1}^m p_k \varphi(x)^k v \end{aligned} φ(p)v=φ(k=1∑m​pk​xk)v=k=1∑m​pk​φ(x)kv​ Similarly, any choice of ϕ(x)∈End(V)\phi(x) \in \End(V)ϕ(x)∈End(V) yields a valid ring homomorphism, exposing a bijection between F[x]\FF[x]F[x]-modules and pairs (V,T∈End(V))(V, T \in \End(V))(V,T∈End(V)). {  F[x]-modules V  }⟷{F-vector spaces V with alinear map T:V→V} \bigg\{ \;\mathbb{F}[x]\text{-modules } V\; \bigg\} \longleftrightarrow \bigg\{ \substack{\small\text{$\mathbb{F}$-vector spaces $V$ with a}\\\small \text{linear map $T : V \rightarrow V$}} \bigg\} {F[x]-modules V}⟷{F-vector spaces V with alinear map T:V→V​} In general, there are many different F[x]\FF[x]F[x]-module structures a given F\FFF-vector space VVV, each corresponding to a choice of linear T:V→VT : V \rightarrow VT:V→V.

The F[x]\FF[x]F[x]-submodules of an F[x]\FF[x]F[x]-module~VVV are precisely the TTT-invariant subspaces of VVV, where T∈End(V)T \in \End(V)T∈End(V) denotes the action of xxx.

Each F[x]\FF[x]F[x]-submodule of VVV is closed under actions by ring elements, including TTT. Likewise, every TTT-invariant subspace is closed under ring actions, which are all polynomials in TTT.

Module Homomorphisms

An RRR-module homomorphism is a map ϕ:M→N\phi : M \rightarrow Nϕ:M→N between modules which respects the RRR-module structure, by preserving addition and commuting with the ring action on MMM, ϕ(x+y)=ϕ(x)+ϕ(y)∀ x,y∈Mϕ(r⋅x)=r⋅ϕ(x)∀ x∈M,r∈R \begin{aligned} \phi(x + y) &= \phi(x) + \phi(y) & \forall\, x,y \in M \\ \phi(r \cdot x) &= r \cdot \phi(x) & \forall\, x \in M, r \in R \end{aligned} ϕ(x+y)ϕ(r⋅x)​=ϕ(x)+ϕ(y)=r⋅ϕ(x)​∀x,y∈M∀x∈M,r∈R​

The kernel of a module homomorphism is its kernel ker⁡ϕ=ϕ−1{0S}\ker \phi = \phi^{-1}\{0_S\}kerϕ=ϕ−1{0S​} as an additive group homomorphism. A bijective RRR-module homomorphism is an isomorphism. For any ring RRR, the set HomR(M,N)\Hom_R(M,N)HomR​(M,N) of homomorphisms between two RRR-modules forms a commutative group under pointwise addition, (ϕ+ψ)(m)=ϕ(m)+ψ(m)(\phi + \psi)(m) = \phi(m) + \psi(m)(ϕ+ψ)(m)=ϕ(m)+ψ(m) for ϕ,ψ∈HomR(M,N)\phi, \psi \in \Hom_R(M,N)ϕ,ψ∈HomR​(M,N). Moreover,

For a commutative ring RRR, the group HomR(M,N)\Hom_R(M,N)HomR​(M,N) forms an RRR-module under the ring action R→End(HomR(M,N))R \rightarrow \End(\Hom_R(M,N))R→End(HomR​(M,N)) given by (r⋅ϕ)(m)≡r⋅ϕ(m)∀ r∈R,m∈M,ϕ∈HomR(M,N) \begin{aligned} (r \cdot \phi)(m) &\equiv r \cdot \phi(m) &\forall\, r \in R, m \in M, \phi \in \Hom_R(M,N) \end{aligned} (r⋅ϕ)(m)​≡r⋅ϕ(m)​∀r∈R,m∈M,ϕ∈HomR​(M,N)​

Commutativity of RRR guarantees that (r⋅ϕ)∈HomR(M,N)(r\cdot \phi) \in \Hom_R(M,N)(r⋅ϕ)∈HomR​(M,N), since (r⋅ϕ)(s⋅m)=r⋅ϕ(s⋅m)(by definition)=rs⋅ϕ(m)(ϕ is a homomorphism)=sr⋅ϕ(m)(commutativity)=s⋅(r⋅ϕ(m))(by definition) \begin{aligned} (r \cdot \phi)(s \cdot m) &= r \cdot \phi(s \cdot m) & \text{(by definition)} \\ &= rs \cdot \phi(m) & \text{(} \phi \text{ is a homomorphism)} \\ &= sr \cdot \phi(m) & \text{(commutativity)} \\ &= s \cdot (r \cdot \phi(m)) & \text{(by definition)} \end{aligned} (r⋅ϕ)(s⋅m)​=r⋅ϕ(s⋅m)=rs⋅ϕ(m)=sr⋅ϕ(m)=s⋅(r⋅ϕ(m))​(by definition)(ϕ is a homomorphism)(commutativity)(by definition)​

Ring of Module Endomorphisms

Endomorphisms HomR(M,M)\Hom_R(M,M)HomR​(M,M) form a unital ring, where (ϕ+ψ)(m)=ϕ(m)+ψ(m)(pointwise addition)(ϕψ)(m)=(ϕ∘ψ)(m)(composition)1HomR(M,M)=IdM(multiplicative identity) \begin{aligned} (\phi + \psi)(m) &= \phi(m) + \psi(m) & \text{(pointwise addition)} \\ (\phi \psi)(m) &= (\phi \circ \psi)(m) & \text{(composition)} \\ 1_{\Hom_R(M,M)} &= \mathrm{Id}_M & \text{(multiplicative identity)} \end{aligned} (ϕ+ψ)(m)(ϕψ)(m)1HomR​(M,M)​​=ϕ(m)+ψ(m)=(ϕ∘ψ)(m)=IdM​​(pointwise addition)(composition)(multiplicative identity)​ We write EndR(M)=HomR(M,M)\End_R(M) = \Hom_R(M,M)EndR​(M)=HomR​(M,M) for the endomorphism ring of MMM.

Let MMM be a module over a commutative ring RRR. The endomorphism ring EndR(M)\End_R(M)EndR​(M) forms an RRR-algebra, under the same ring action r↦φ(φr:m↦rm)r \stackrel{\varphi}{\mapsto} ( \varphi_r : m \mapsto rm)r↦φ​(φr​:m↦rm) which defines MMM as an RRR-module.

This property is normally stated without reference to ring homomorphisms, but in these notes we wish to emphasize that the study of modules is really the study of . There is at least one subtlety, though: When defining MMM as an RRR-module, we required that φ⊡:R→End(M,+)\varphi_\boxdot : R \rightarrow \End(M,+)φ⊡​:R→End(M,+) be a ring homomorphism from RRR to the additive group endomorphisms on (M,+)(M,+)(M,+). Now, we are asking whether each φr\varphi_rφr​ is also an RRR-module homomorphism.

First, the additive group homomorphism φr∈End(M,+)\varphi_r \in \End(M,+)φr​∈End(M,+) is also a module homomorphism, since for r,s∈Rr,s \in Rr,s∈R and m∈Mm \in Mm∈M, φr(s⋅m)=r⋅(s⋅m)(by definition)=(rs)⋅m1(associativity of scalars)=s⋅(r⋅m)(associativity of scalars)=s⋅φr(m)(by definition) \begin{aligned} \varphi_r(s \cdot m) &= r \cdot (s \cdot m) &\text{(by definition)} \\ &= (rs) \cdot m_1 &\hspace{4em}\text{(associativity of scalars)}\\ &= s \cdot (r \cdot m) &\text{(associativity of scalars)}\\ &= s \cdot \varphi_r(m) &\text{(by definition)} \end{aligned} φr​(s⋅m)​=r⋅(s⋅m)=(rs)⋅m1​=s⋅(r⋅m)=s⋅φr​(m)​(by definition)(associativity of scalars)(associativity of scalars)(by definition)​ Futher, φ⊡:R↦EndR(M)\varphi_\boxdot : R \mapsto \End_R(M)φ⊡​:R↦EndR​(M) sending r↦φrr \mapsto \varphi_rr↦φr​ is a ring homomorphism. φr1+r2(m)=(r1+r2)⋅m(by definition)=r1⋅m+r2⋅m(distributivity of scalars)=φr1(m)+φr2(m)(by definition)φr1r2(m)=(r1r2)⋅m(by definition)=r2⋅(r1⋅m)(R commutative)=(φr2∘φr1)(m)(by definition) \begin{aligned} \varphi_{r_1 + r_2}(m) &= (r_1 + r_2) \cdot m &\text{(by definition)} \\ &= r_1 \cdot m + r_2 \cdot m &\text{(distributivity of scalars)} \\ &= \varphi_{r_1}(m) + \varphi_{r_2}(m) &\text{(by definition)} \\ \varphi_{r_1 r_2}(m) &= (r_1 r_2) \cdot m & \text{(by definition)} \\ &= r_2 \cdot (r_1 \cdot m) &\text{($R$ commutative)} \\ &= (\varphi_{r_2} \circ \varphi_{r_1})(m) &\text{(by definition)} \end{aligned} φr1​+r2​​(m)φr1​r2​​(m)​=(r1​+r2​)⋅m=r1​⋅m+r2​⋅m=φr1​​(m)+φr2​​(m)=(r1​r2​)⋅m=r2​⋅(r1​⋅m)=(φr2​​∘φr1​​)(m)​(by definition)(distributivity of scalars)(by definition)(by definition)(R commutative)(by definition)​ Finally, each φr\varphi_rφr​ commutes with every element ϕ∈EndR(M)\phi \in \End_R(M)ϕ∈EndR​(M), (φr∘ϕ)(m)=φr(ϕ(m))(composition)=r⋅ϕ(m)(by definition)=ϕ(r⋅m)(module homomorphism)=ϕ(φr(m))(by definition) \begin{aligned} (\varphi_r \circ \phi)(m) &= \varphi_r (\phi(m)) &\text{(composition)} \\ &= r \cdot \phi(m) &\text{(by definition)}\\ &= \phi(r \cdot m) &\text{(module homomorphism)}\\ &= \phi( \varphi_r(m)) &\text{(by definition)} \end{aligned} (φr​∘ϕ)(m)​=φr​(ϕ(m))=r⋅ϕ(m)=ϕ(r⋅m)=ϕ(φr​(m))​(composition)(by definition)(module homomorphism)(by definition)​

By definition, every field F\FFF is a commutative ring. Therefore, the endomorphisms EndF(V)\End_\FF(V)EndF​(V) of any F\FFF-vector space form an F\FFF-algebra.

Quotient Modules

For groups and rings, recall that quotients are well-defined only for subgroups and subrings (ideals), respectively. For modules MMM, it turns out that submodule N⩽MN \subspace MN⩽M has a quotient M/NM / NM/N, and the natural projection map π:M→M/N\pi : M \rightarrow M/Nπ:M→M/N is a ring homomorphism with kernel ker⁡π=N\ker \pi = Nkerπ=N. Similarly, each F\FFF-vector subspace has a quotient F\FFF-vector space arising as the kernel of some linear map.

Let RRR be a ring. Let N⩽MN \subspace MN⩽M be a submodule of the RRR-module MMM. The (additive, commutative) quotient group M/NM / NM/N can be made into an RRR-module under the ring action R→End(M/N)R \rightarrow \End(M/N)R→End(M/N) given by r⋅(x+N)=(r⋅x)+N∀ r∈R,x+N∈M/N \begin{aligned} r \cdot (x + N) &= (r \cdot x) + N &\forall\, r \in R, x + N \in M/N \end{aligned} r⋅(x+N)​=(r⋅x)+N​∀r∈R,x+N∈M/N​ The natural projection π:M→M/N\pi : M \rightarrow M/Nπ:M→M/N mapping x↦x+Nx \mapsto x+Nx↦x+N is an RRR-module homomorphism with kernel ker⁡π=N\ker\pi = Nkerπ=N.

(First Isomorphism Theorem) Let M,NM,NM,N be RRR-modules. The kernel of any module homomorphism ϕ:M→N\phi : M \rightarrow Nϕ:M→N is a submodule of MMM, and M/ker⁡ϕ≅ϕ(M) M / \ker\phi \cong \phi(M) M/kerϕ≅ϕ(M)

Free Modules

The vector space concepts of linear combinations, bases, and span all have analogues in RRR-module theory. We normally assume RRR is a ring with identity.

Let MMM be an RRR-module. The submodule of MMM generated by a subset A⊂MA \subset MA⊂M is the set of finite RRR-linear combinations RA={r1a1+⋯+rmam∣rk∈R,ak∈A,m∈N}⩽M RA = \{ r_1 a_1 + \cdots + r_m a_m \mid r_k \in R, a_k \in A, m \in \NN \} \subspace M RA={r1​a1​+⋯+rm​am​∣rk​∈R,ak​∈A,m∈N}⩽M A submodule N=RA⩽MN = RA \subspace MN=RA⩽M is if A⊂MA \subset MA⊂M is finite. A cyclic submodule N=RaN = RaN=Ra is generated by a single element a∈Ma \in Ma∈M.

An RRR-module FFF is free on the subset A⊂FA \subset FA⊂F if each nonzero x∈Fx \in Fx∈F expands uniquely as an RRR-linear combination of elements from AAA, in which case AAA is called a basis for FFF. x=r1a1+⋯+rmam∃! rk∈R,ak∈A,∀ x∈F \begin{aligned} x &= r_1 a_1 + \cdots + r_m a_m & \exists!\, r_k \in R, a_k \in A, \forall\, x \in F \end{aligned} x​=r1​a1​+⋯+rm​am​​∃!rk​∈R,ak​∈A,∀x∈F​

In general, more than one basis may exist. If RRR is commutative, every basis has the same cardinality, called the of FFF. Unlike for vector spaces, not every module has a basis (not every module is free).

Universal Property of Free Modules

Recall that every linear map T∈HomF(V,W)T \in \Hom_\FF(V,W)T∈HomF​(V,W) between F\FFF-vector spaces is uniquely determined by its value on n=dim⁡Vn=\dim Vn=dimV points. RRR-linear maps between free modules enjoy the same property, which is normally stated in the following way:

(Universal Property) For any set AAA, there is a unique (up to isomorphism) free RRR-module Free(A)\mathrm{Free}(A)Free(A) satisfying the following universal property: for any RRR-module MMM and any function φ:A→M\varphi : A \rightarrow Mφ:A→M, there is a unique RRR-module homomorphism Φ:Free(A)→M\Phi : \mathrm{Free}(A) \rightarrow MΦ:Free(A)→M such that Φ(a)=φ(a)\Phi(a) = \varphi(a)Φ(a)=φ(a),
